text:
Thanks for joining. Every successful startup
has a founding story which they reinvent as
they get more successful.

But here you're among friends. So it'd be really
interesting to hear the real story of how
you came up with the idea

and what you did and
where it came from. And it sounds like
before Vannevar, you

had an interesting career
first starting at McKinsey. And was McKinsey
right out of college? Yeah, right out of college.
Where'd you go to school? University of Georgia. Oh, some other school. Some other school. And what made you join McKinsey?

I actually wanted
to do a math PhD, but my math advisor at
the time told me, hey,

you are not good enough to
get into MIT or Stanford as a PhD student. And so I was looking at--

I was looking around
at job options. And some of the smartest people
that I knew from undergrad were going to McKinsey.

And so I thought, hey, I'll
throw my name in the hat. And that's honestly how
I ended up in the door. I was not very well
thought out other than--

Yeah, McKinsey is a great place. Yeah. So how'd you end up
in national security? Did you pick it?

Or-- Yeah. --work your way into it? Or-- Yeah, as soon as I got into
McKinsey, the first projects that I was working on were
consumer goods related,

like, for example, like baby
lotion pricing in Brazil, which to me was
extremely uninteresting.

But you're now probably the best
domain expert in the world in-- Yeah. --baby lotion. Anybody have any baby
lotion in Brazil questions?

Yeah, I can tell you
how they price it. But I think-- And Portuguese. Yes, yeah.

And pretty quickly
I knew that, that was not what I wanted to do. I have a family background
with both my grandparents

in the military and
national security. And in particular, some of the
stuff that was going on in Asia

has been of interest to me. And so I joined a
research group actually when I was in undergrad
that was focused on that.

And, yeah, just right
when I got to McKinsey, I just tried to weasel my
way into the D.C. office

and started to get staff
on some of the projects that I was hearing about in the
defense and intelligence space.

And did you end up there
in the D.C. office? Yes. Yeah, I left. Physically did you move? Physically, yes,
moved from Atlanta

to D.C. maybe eight months in. And what did you work on? I worked on a
couple of projects. I worked with some of
the defense primes,

for example, Lockheed and others
on technology strategy, which gave me a very
interesting view in terms

of some of these primes
that make a lot of money from the government, what their
executive teams are like, how

they think. Interesting view is usually an
euphemism much more interesting than that, interesting. Anything you want to share?

I was not particularly
impressed, I guess. And why was that? I mean, we-- What's your take
on large companies?

Yeah, we-- I mean, was a It was me and a few other
analysts that were literally writing the technology strategy
for some of these business

units that were multi-billion
dollar business units in these defense companies. And we were not domain experts.

So the fact that we were
doing that kind of work, and that was how strategy
was being developed
was honestly terrifying. But, yeah, so I think--

yeah, I worked with
some of the primes, and then I moved over
to work with some of the government on the
intelligence community side.

And that's when I really fell in
love with the National Security mission. And was this when we were
chasing non-nation states?

Or-- This was pre-nation state days. This was back in the
counterterrorism days.

And what did the
mission feel like? I was instantly
hooked to be honest.

So the agency I was working
with, very sensitive about,

how, yeah, what
you can talk about. But the people that I met while
working with that agency were

some of the smartest and most
mission-driven people that I've ever met and had
done some of the most--

had put themselves
in physical danger or were operating in
a space that was-- I don't know, the
fact that people

were willing to make
that sacrifice to me was-- and were really smart,
and they were really driven,

all of us, but just decided
to go a different path, that to me was extremely motivating. Did it feel different than
having worked with the primes?

Yeah. Yeah, 100%, I think. Yeah, I think with
government, you have this--

a lot of people
in DOD and the IC. And there's a lot of
noise and bureaucracy

and things that don't
work particularly well. But there are pockets
of people that are doing really amazing work. And it's when you find
those pockets that's

when it's really
exciting to work with those types of groups. Sounds like you're still
excited about the work you did.

Yes. Yeah, for sure. How long did you stay
working with them? I was at McKinsey for
about three years.

That's about the typical
McKinsey tour for all of you. It was like a year
longer, a year longer.

I spent probably
two years of that working on defense and
intelligence related things, and then I hopped to
In-Q-Tel from McKinsey.

And were you recruited? Or did you find them? It was this guy Dan Gwak
emailed the McKinsey D.C. office

with the job description. And I read the job description,
and I was like, yes, I would like to do this. What was the job description?

Go invest in technology
startups for CIA. That was-- I was like,
yeah, I want to do that.

Sounds great. Yeah, yeah. And what was that job like? That job was really fun. I think-- yeah, I liked it
because I had a lot of--

Remind people-- they all
saw Bowsher, I think. But remind people the mission
of In-Q-Tel one more time.

Yeah, the mission
of In-Q-Tel is just to basically provide CIA
access to technology literally

out in Silicon Valley. It was founded with
offices in Menlo Park. And traditionally,
the people that

develop technology for
the IC specifically are all out in Reston,
Virginia, really niche, small engineering shops that are
building products for people.

And the whole
purpose of In-Q-Tel was trying to take
the things that were going on in Silicon Valley
in the '90s and early 2000

and push them in. And it's evolved over time. But that was the
initial mission. And your role was a
specific piece of this.

Yeah. So I worked on computer
vision and NLP back in 2016. And I worked specifically with
the counterterrorism mission

center at CIA. That's where I spent
most of my time. My goal was to spend as
much time in the building

with those people as possible. That was where I got the
most energy in that job. Yeah, a lot of this
would be relevant for how you scale Vannevar Labs.

But I think it's a great
point you just make. We'll come back to
in about 10 minutes. Yeah. Yeah, yeah.

And so just tripling
down on that, so you got close to the problem. Yeah. That's a big idea. Why don't you-- maybe
do you mind, Paul,

if we embellish it now? Yes. Yeah. What did that give you versus
sitting outside the wire?

Yeah. At the time the major problem
for CIA was the Islamic state. This was back in 2016.

And you can't-- because
literally people at CIA will

not tell, you can't actually
figure out what the mission is without going into their
physical spaces and physically watching them do their job.

The thing that
really was an unlock for me was partnering with-- I found somebody on the
government side who's amazing.

I still keep in touch with her. That was a senior
analyst in that group.

And she had relationships
with everybody. So I just latched on
to her, and then we just walked around and went
to all these different mission

groups and looked at
what they were doing. And that by far-- I mean, that-- you
really don't know

what to invest in
unless you know what the actual underlying
mission problems are at that level of detail.

So getting as close as
possible to the customer was a key learning. Yeah. Yeah, yeah.

And specifically
for me, it was-- we would go on site
with the customer, and we would meet with
them in conference rooms. And that does not cut it.

You have to physically
go behind their desk and watch them do the thing
that they're tasked to do. So literally understand the
day in the life of a customer

by watching them and being
able to go up the whiteboard and draw what you think you saw. Yeah.

Now, didn't they have the
quick that was supposedly good? Yeah. There are parts of the
government that are maybe

a little bit more bureaucratic. And I think that's actually
one of the key lessons that I

learned from In-Q-Tel is-- and this is not to
pick on The Quick. But there are these-- Why don't you explain
what The Quick is?

The Quick is an innovation
group within CIA whose job it is to interface
between the mission, and users,

and the company,
and the [INAUDIBLE].. To do what you were
doing personally. Yeah, exactly. And when you separate the
product, people, and engineers

that are building the stuff
from the mission end users, and you have a go between
sitting in the middle, you 100%

of the time have
much worse results. So that was one of the
things that I learned, yeah.

And I think as Paul
said, we're going to talk about that when we
talk about Vannevar Labs. Yeah. And so was it fun?

I had a lot of fun. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. Steve Bowsher actually gave me
a tremendous amount of leeway to just try things.

And how many of you were there? On the investment-- you mean
overall in the investment? Yes.

I think there was maybe on the investment team,
something like that. And so what made you
leave if it was so great?

I saw one particular
mission problem that was related to this
Islamic state mission.

And I could not figure
out how to solve it at the In-Q-Tel side. I could not figure
out how to do it.

I tried to find companies and
push them into the building, and that wasn't working.

Because? The tech wasn't ready? Or they couldn't modify
it for the problem?

Or they weren't cleared enough? The premise of In-Q-Tel,
which has some validity-- I'm about to knock it
for a second though.

The premise of In-Q-Tel
of dual use technology always is the
answer is not right.

You can build-- if you try
to take something commercial

off the shelf and just jam
it onto a particular mission problem, you're
not-- the people that are building that
commercial product usually don't have the domain expertise
to actually build it exactly

to the mission. Do you just plain dual
use or use a global set that because it's a big
philosophical difference? Yeah, yeah.

Dual use is this theory
that existed pre-Paul Kwan. And some of the defense
investors that you can only

invest in defense
companies if they have both a commercial
and defense business, you can't invest in pure defense
companies and disproved this.

We are one of the
other companies in the space that fundamentally
disagrees with this theory. But at the time, that was
the prevailing wisdom is

you have to be dual use
in order to be successful. And that I saw
firsthand at In-Q-Tel

that, that was
actually not the case. The most important mission
problems were not dual use by nature yet the
government was also

spending hundreds of
millions of dollars on these systems
built by Raytheon, which does not have the
best software engineers that

weren't working. So it wasn't like a
mission problem was there. The money was there.

But you needed to-- my take
was if you could bring together the right product people and
engineers and the right people

with domain expertise,
you could really build things that were
fundamentally different

in the defense space. That's why you went to school. Yeah. So exactly. Well, let me just challenge that
for the sake of a conversation

to you and Paul as well. So knowing what you
know now, would there

have been a way to get
people in a dual use company deep enough in front
of the customer

to actually make them useful? So the best dual
use companies that I

see operating right
now, probably I would say Scale AI is maybe
one of the better ones.

And the trick with-- so Scale AI does a lot of NLP
trains, all the LMS for OpenAI.

They have a massive
government business. The problem with
companies like Scale and when it comes to
defense is usually

their engineering teams have
to split their prioritization. And when that
prioritization split

happens, usually
naturally they're And what that means
is you basically

R&D engineering starve
the defense product, and you end up-- your
sales people then end up having to jam a
commercial product down

into DOD, which can work if you
have a really great sales team. So it's the financial
math that doesn't work.

I think it's-- Allocating. And like we talked about
with Teresa Carlson at AWS,

how many of the
engineers are going to pass top secret
clearances and get into the building of the
best engineers at Amazon?

You lose attrition. And so how do you get
the very best people working on the hardest
problems [INAUDIBLE]?? All right.

Well, good. Yeah. And so you were doing this. You realized that there
might be a better way

to solve the problem. What made you go get your MBA? Yeah, it took me a year from
seeing that initial break

in that Islamic state
technology problem set to having the
realization that you might be able to raise money and
build a company in this space.

That process was super slow. It took me like a year
because I kept thinking about, Why is this not working?

Why can't I affect it here? Is there another
company I can join? I didn't see another
company that I can join.

So it took like a year
of noodling on it. Pretty fast. Well, I don't know, it
felt like a long time. It feels like a long time.

That's pretty fast. Yeah. Yeah. And then I was thinking about,
OK, how do I start this? I didn't know if
we were going to be

able to raise money because
at the time, nobody cared. Defense was not an
interesting topic--

Until Paul came. --until Paul came along. And so for me, I use business
school as a hedge basically.

It's like, all right,
I want to go in. I want to start this thing. I don't know how long it's
going to take to raise. I don't know if it's going to
be three months, or three years,

or never. You always had baby
lotion to fall back. I always said had-- I could always go
back into consulting.

Yeah. Yeah, yeah. So you went to business
school with the idea that you wanted
to start a company but were going to
get some more skills.

It was purely just to buy time. To buy time. I spent not a lot of time in my
classes, unfortunately which--

And did you actually start the
company in business school? Yeah, we-- Nini and I
incorporated it in--

I think, it was January
of our first year, so it was four
months into school. And who is Nini?

Nini is my co-founder. And was she also in
business school with you? Yes. Yeah, yeah.

Yeah. And did you have in mind the
product you wanted to solve? I did, which in retrospect
was honestly a mistake.

How so? I thought you
understood the problem. I thought I understood, yeah. I think, yeah, we knew
what we wanted to build.

And Nini was an end
user that experienced that same problem
with her background was in the
intelligence community

as an analyst like deployed in
Afghanistan and other places. And she experienced the same
problem that I experienced. And so the idea
was, can we-- we're

going to build this
thing, and then we're going to sell it into the groups
that we used to work with. It's going to be great. The problem was that
the delta between when

I saw the problem
in the building and when we actually got
money and then engineers and then started to
build stuff, that delta

was like a year and
a half, two years. And at that point, your
information is totally stale. Yeah.

Yeah. And, yeah, there's
this pivot in 2019, counterterrorism

towards Russia and China. As it should. As it should have. But that meant the thing we
built nobody wanted to buy.

Kept doing all these demos,
nobody wanted to buy our stuff. I see. So the problem had changed. It wasn't that the
methodology was wrong, that we

were no longer in front of-- you didn't have your tickets,
or access, or whatever. Yeah, exactly. And so what did you do?

We did a ton of demos. We try to build
allotted for features. Again, this is when we--
we're not super sophisticated

in product-- try to build a lot of
features, doing a lot of demos. We couldn't figure out
if it was the product or if it was us not
knowing how to sell. And eventually we
started hearing people--

nobody would call us back. But we would hear from
time to time people saying Russia or China
like, hey, this is great.

You're doing this for Arabic and
other languages in the middle east. Can you do anything for
Mandarin or Russian?

And after I ignored that, again,
like the great product person that I am, I ignored that for
like three or four months,

and eventually we had literally
nothing to lose at this point. We had a meeting in
D.C. the following week.

And one of the engineers
in the team and I decided, all right, we're going
to build a VCO thing for one

of those languages. We built that, and then
we started demoing that. And that's the first
time we had actual poles.

The core engine concept
for Arabic versus Mandarin was not dissimilar--

Yeah, that's right. --language. Yeah, yeah. So big idea for all
of you, this was a pivot, a substantive pivot.

Yeah. Yeah. And back to Paul's point
that the core architecture didn't get thrown out, but
the business model changed.

And the target customers and
the users inside the building changed. Yeah.

That's right. You're no longer talking to
the folks who are working on Isis or Al-Qaeda problems. You're talking
about people working on China and Russia, different
sides of buildings, et cetera.

Yep. And therefore, you needed
to make new friends and learn new parts
of the organization.

Yes. Yeah. And how long did that take? It probably took
us way too long.

I mean-- Year or months? Yeah, probably nine
months, I would say. And that's like I'm giving
us a little bit more credit.

It's probably nine
months generously. I think our first
actual deployment--

our first, real traction
with our first deployment was probably 18 months into
the life of the company.

And we probably made the pivot
to China and Russia maybe I mean, that's a long time.

Again, there's something
you just pointed out. A pivot doesn't
come with a memo.

You didn't get a memo that
says, hey, you're wrong. We're telling you you're wrong. Your VCs didn't-- or early
investors didn't know what you

knew. They just were happy
to be investing in you because you
were smart, and you had these relationships.

But it took you guys to collect
enough data for the light bulb to go on that says that
buzzing sound we're hearing

is probably not noise. It's probably a signal. Is that a fair way
to describe it? Yeah, yeah. And I think for all of you
who are going to do start up

careers, you should this is
that your odds of nailing it-- and Paul will push back-- the product is close to zero.

It's being able to
listen to the market. And sometimes you just can't
get your head out of the way

because you put so much
effort into product one, which we thought were perfect
because you thought you understood the customer.

Is that true? Yeah, yeah. So, Paul, before I hand
it off to you in funding,

so were you funded at this
time with money from Paul? Yeah, yeah. It was Katherine Boyle
at General Catalyst.

That was the-- yeah, that was
the origins of the company was we raised. And did you get funded when
you were Stanford students?

Or did you drop out? When we were students
and then subsequently dropped out as per prior
conditions of the term sheet.

All right. Well, Paul, should I
hand it over to you? Yeah, let me just give people
a sense for where you are today

so they can understand where
the story, and let's go back and fill in the pieces. So we'll come back
to the funding

and some of the struggles. But give a sense for like what's
happened in the last two years because the trajectory
of Vannevar Labs

from a financial and
adoption standpoint is really unparalleled in our
estimation vis-a-vis other

companies defense tech. And so we want to unpack that. But just lay out what's
happened in the last two years that's pretty remarkable.

Yeah. It is remarkable. It's been wild. Yeah, we went from about to about 50 million
in 24 months.

And we went from like 20 people
to maybe around 100 people, one product to four
or five products.

We've been profitable
for about a year. That was a huge deal for us. The Series B--
Raised some money, yeah. Some money? Raised 75 million Series B.

You all should be so lucky. I think you wrote
this blog post,

how to invent defense
products, a year or two ago. It's a really highly worth
reading and tracking down.

I think a lot of those
things still stand and are worth unpacking. I think we're all
waiting for part 2, which

is about how to scale a
defense company, which you're doing in real time. But I think just going back
towards some of those rules,

I think, are worth
unpacking vis-a-vis mission, user understanding. Maybe start to unpack
that because that's

the critical piece that
got you from zero to three to, in my estimation, to 50. Yeah, yeah.

I think I don't
know how many of you all are interested in
the product development side of things from
a startup standpoint.

But the key things that
we learned in defense are for defense in
particular, you can't--

and at this point, you've really
[INAUDIBLE] businesses, too. But for defense in particular,
you cannot build a thing and sell it unless it's solving
a top-three mission problem

in the DOD. It needs to be, no joke, one
of the most urgent problems

in the entire department
of defense in order to get enough excitement for
the procurement engine to move.

And so when we think about
making product bets, that is one of the key-- that's
one of the main things

that we look for is like,
Is this a top three problem? Or is it a top 10 problem? If it's a top 10
problem, you're not going to be able
to sell anything.

That sounds really obvious,
but it's not at all obvious when you're in there.

As you're building
the product, you're constantly trying to sell it. And as you're trying
to sell it, you're getting information on like is
this the right thing or not.

Am I getting pull or not? So you use the word
irrationally excited. Can people get
irrationally excited?

What does that
actually feel like, look like when you're
doing the work? Yeah, I mean your pitch-- it's like pitching a
kernel and that kernel

in the meeting stopping
you and thanking you for what you're doing. We're not able to do this.

You're providing a national
security capability that we don't have access to. Or it's like--

This has happened. It sounds crazy. But we've gotten like-- our team has gotten standing
ovations from user groups
a couple times, not very often. But that's unusual for DOD. It's not normal for--

imagine you using
a software product, and you have some people
that built the product come into your space.

To feel that way about
something that people use is really hard to generate. But in DOD, you have to generate
that level of enthusiasm

because the
procurement process is so hard for all of the buyers.

You need people to really want
to burn down bridges for you.

So that's what we mean. That's the main thing for
product development in DOD, I would say, yeah.

And then you talk a lot
about, as Steve mentioned, understanding what the
users need, what they do.

Yeah. How did you-- I mean, you obviously had
some access, Nini as well. How do you get that access?

How do you get
behind someone's desk to see what they're actually
doing in these use cases? Yeah, it's really
tough in the beginning

when you don't have
clearances, and you don't have existing
relationships to get you on military bases.

In that if you're
in that scenario, then you really need to
rely on friends that are in.

You actually have a
couple of GSB folks that are in the veterans
club in the back here. Those are the kinds of people
that you want to tap and then

use them to get to their network
and understand what the mission problems are from the outside. That will get you a
decent amount of the way,

but your iteration cycles
are going to be a lot slower. It might take you 12 months
to iterate to something that it would otherwise
take you two months if you

had a clearance. When you have a clearance,
it becomes a lot easier because then you're
able to just--

you need to have-- when you're doing
product development, you need to have a product
person partnered with like a BD

person, basically a sales
person, that is constantly mapping out the organizations
that you're trying to get into

and then getting
you access to them. That partnership is
really, really key. If you don't have that,
you're in for a tough time.

But if you have
that partnership, and you're cleared,
then it's very easy to get on base with people. And whenever we go
on base with people,

we never pitch them a product. This is a sales tactic. But you never pitch
people the product.

Demo it, talk about
the buttons, that's the worst you could possibly do. Instead we do a lot of prep
time on the mission of the group

that we're pitching to. In some cases, a couple
of weeks of prep time, really understanding
what the mission is

and then just showing our
stuff on that mission. So when you're going
on these bases,

you're walking in with
immediate value to them. And then it's easy to
ask like, hey, this looks interesting to you.

Can walk me down to your
end users or these people down the hall?

Also I think we skipped over
what the first product is, whatever disclosure we can say?

Yeah, yeah. The gist of it-- the thesis that we had
was a couple of things.

One is government is
really terrible at parsing foreign language data. That was the very basic
theory of the first product.

And in 2016, 2017, 2018, and
now obviously today, there's a lot of tools that you can use
to make foreign language data

a lot more easy to process. For example, machine
translation, used to not be very good. Now it's actually
pretty amazing.

At the same time, there
was this massive pivot from counterterrorism
to Asia and Europe.

And the government
collection mechanisms that existed for
counterterrorism don't work super well for
like Russia and China.

You can't necessarily
fly an air asset overhead some of these places in a safe
way to collect information.

So you need a different
forms of intelligence in order to enable
those missions. And the way that
manifested is we'd

go on these military bases, we'd
go look at the Intel analysts, and we'd go look at
what they were doing. And it'd be like Google--
people google searching stuff.

Like Google translate searching. Yeah, like Russia
and playing in--

that kind of thing. And so that tells you
that there's something broken in that process.

And so the first
product that we built was around collecting
data that we thought would allow
people to answer

more useful, complicated,
more urgent mission questions. And then the tech
stuff we had to build

to do that was around
secure data collection and then processing of image,
video, text, data, yeah.

So we go back. So that's where we've gone from. Let's go back to
initial fundraising,

super fast, super glamorous,
just money's coming in the door. No, absolutely not.

I wish that's how it went. How many meetings? Yeah, for our seed round,
it took me six months.

And that's not a
light six months. I'm doing this part time. That's I'm doing this
full-- every day,

all day I'm waking up at 5:00 in
the morning with panic attack. Like, oh, what do I need
to change in the pitch? This is not zoom world where you
can do 10 pitches in one day?

You've got to drive around. This is drive around
up and down 101 to 80. Exactly. These are the olden days.

But, yeah, it took us
probably 40, I would say,

more diligence meetings on top of that but 40 pitches to
distinct VCs to get one offer.

And that was
Katherine Boyle in GC. So can I ask, Just how did
your pitch change from day one

to the one where
you got the check? What did you learn? Yes, great question. Yeah, so the thing that
I didn't appreciate

is you have to think about
your pitch as a product, and you're iterating on it until
you find fit with an investor.

And the-- I would say a
lot of things I learned, we were iterating every week. We would do a pitch, we'd
hear where people were getting

stuck, and then we
would figure out what we could change to
address those points. The biggest thing that I
learned from the seed round

was we were trying
to dance around the hard issues in the business. Terms like DOD is actually
very difficult customer.

You can't do a seed pitch
to start a defense company and not address things
like, how are you going to win programs
which take a long time,

require a lot of
bureaucratic maneuvering? And so I initially would try
to skirt around those issues.

Like, no, you don't need
to worry about that. We're going to figure it out. It's going to be great. And the ultimately what ended
up resonating with people

is I just made a slide. It was like here are
all the things that you have to believe about
us in order for this

Yeah, yeah. I think honestly, yeah, we
made about 2 and 1/2 years worth of mistakes, which
is quite a long time when

you're in it. I think the some of the
things that we learned that were totally
not obvious to me is the best-- the biggest
deals that we've ever done

haven't just been
a sales person. We've always had three-- a trio. We've always had a sales
person, an engineer,

a customer-facing engineer, and
a product person in the deal. And we didn't use to do that.

And the second we
started combining product and engineering
and a sales person and allocating those to
the most important deals,

our deal sizes went up by,
like, 5X, and our time to close went down a lot as well. This is literally making sure
three people go to the meeting.

Yes. The product person comes with
a really compelling mission demo, that's their only job. You're going to spend
two weeks obsessing

over whatever the most-- the highest impact
thing we can show them is, the engineers there to
just lend technical credibility

and talk about exciting,
cool things that we're doing. And then the sales person is
doing insane amount of pre-work

in terms of who
the group is, who the people are to
the level of each of their individual
incentives are.

What are the minefields that
we don't want to step in? Sometimes bringing on advisors
well before the meeting

to understand-- to build that base
of information. But, yeah, if you set up
deal teams with that trio,

your odds of success go way up. So that would be
first thing that I would say for people that are
trying to sell into defense is do it with a team.

Do not do it with a
single salesperson. I mean, yeah, I mean, Nini
built out the whole sales

organization and
our sales strategy. But I think the other
thing that we really didn't understand the
importance of until about two to three years in is the
importance of program offices

and program managers, which are
these groups in the government that have a lot
of money that are often extremely disconnected
from the mission and the end

user. Yeah, you would
explain why they are important what they control? Don't they write
the requirements? Yeah, they write
the requirements.

Why don't you
explain what that is? So the requirements,
basically that-- this is going to sound insane
when I describe it.

But there's a three-year
budgeting process called the NDAA-- There you go. --where the government
today is setting

their budget for 2027
for what tools technology they're going to buy. Now, if you think about
that from a software product

standpoint, that makes no
sense because the problems that you're going
to have in 2027 are not the same problems that
you're going to have in 2024.

So automatically, you have
a huge challenge there from a sales standpoint. So when we are selling
stuff this year,

we're not just selling for we're trying to get baked into
the budget for 2027 three years

down the line. That's extremely
difficult to do when you have a six-month existing
customer relationship,

and you're going six months
and you're like, hey, I know we're doing
good stuff now. Let's talk about three
years down the line.

How much do you want to budget? It's a really hard
conversation to have. That budget is deployed by these
groups called program offices,

which, not all of
it, but a lot of it is deployed with
these groups called program offices that are
separate from the end user

mission groups. So you'll have
some program office that's tasked with deploying
a particular type of software

in a particular group or
particular type of hardware. But they are not--
this is very key. They're not the same people
that are using the software

or using the hardware. When you're doing
a deal, you have to marry those two groups up
in order to get anything done.

And so you're basically-- I mean, you're playing like
a multi-dimensional game of chess.

That's the long-term revenue. How did you get
short-term revenue? So this is-- again, I
don't know if this is going to be useful for anybody.

But for defense-- Getting short-term revenue is
always useful in [INAUDIBLE].. It's always, always useful. Keeps you in business.

The most important thing
for defense companies for short-term revenue is this
process called the UFR process,

Unfunded Requirements Process. Thank you. Yeah. So basically, in any given
year, maybe 80% of the budget

is going to be spent on
these programs, 20% of it is up for grabs basically. You can work with
your program manager

to run this UFR process to get
allocated some of that 20%. There's other things you
can do within your exit--

in your money,
including reprogramming. Taking money away from
existing programs, that's super dangerous
because now you've

made an enemy somewhere
with a defense prime. But your main route
is these UFRs.
